awd_titl_txt: REU SITE: Physics and Astrophysics at TCU
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Texas Christian University provides eight undergraduate students the opportunity to participate in ten weeks of research on topics in atomic, molecular, bio, chemical, and statistical physics, as well as astronomy and planetary science. The main goal of the program is to provide a memorable and potentially career-defining experience for student participants, who may not have a clear direction of career path upon entering the program. Thoughtfully-selected field trips, weekly discussions with other students and faculty, and workshops on career-planning are vital components of the REU program, providing opportunities for students to consider a broad range of career possibilities and professions in physics and engineering-related fields extending beyond the focused summer research project. 

In addition to participating in research with an experienced mentor, the REU students will engage in weekly activities to ensure not only that their research stays on track but that they have an engaging collegial and scholarly experience. By the end of the program, every student will have given a formal presentation about their work and prepared a conference poster and a 10-page report.  This award is supported by the Division of Physics and the Division of Astronomical Sciences within NSF's Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Texas Christian University (TCU) Physics and Astronomy REU site was funded to support eight students for a nine-ten week REU program with research primarily in Physics, Biophysics, and Astronomy.  The primary goal of the program is to enhance the number of students from small, non-research focused colleges and under-represented groups into the STEM workforce. The primary focus of REU students during the program involved full-time, hands-on scientific research of a specific research problem with a faculty adviser. Weekly REU Group Meetings are held for both science and professional development workshops.  REU students also participate in fields trip to off-campus sites, for example McDonald Observatory.  The summer experience ends with each student presenting an oral research presentation to TCU undergraduate and graduate students and faculty.  REU Participants learned from their faculty advisor, their research group mentor, and from each other, and about other areas of physics through weekly science talk and lab tours given by faculty not advising REU students. The REU program included sessions on graduate school, industry careers, mentoring, and scientific communication. 


Intellectual Merit.  Undergraduates researchers gained an appreciation of modern research in physics & astronomy through completion an independent research project.  They also developed new skills and gained in-depth knowledge in their research area, and were exposed to research in other areas through field trips, lab tours, and oral presentations. The weekly professional development workshops included discussion of careers in science and graduate education.  Graduate student mentors experienced a valuable learning experience in leadership.  


Broader Impacts.  REU students completed the program with a greater understanding for modern scientific research, and gained a sense of confidence of their abilities to enable them to pursue a career in STEM.  Students prepare a poster that many present at a regional of nation scientific conference, including the American Physical Society and American Astronomical Society, along with PowerPoint slides after giving an oral presentation at the completion of the program.  This funding grant provided full and partial prgram support in the summer 2019-2023.  During the 2020-2021 due to COVID-19 undergraduates participated in virtual professional develeopment and research. Eight student were funded by this grant each summer from 2019-2023.
